Title:
Pararhabdodon isonensis and Tsintaosaurus spinorhinus: a new
clade of lambeosaurine hadrosaurids from Eurasia.
Keywords:
Dinosauria; Hadrosauridae; Koutalisaurus; Lambeosaurinae;
Pararhabdodon; Tsintaosaurus
Abstract:
We present new anatomical information showing that
Koutalisaurus kohlerorum, from the Maastrichtian of Lleida Province,
northeastern Spain, is most probably the junior synonym of Pararhabdodon
isonensis from the same region. Dentary and maxillary characters
previously considered as autapomorphies of K. kohlerorum and P.
isonensis, respectively, are shown to be synapomorphies uniting the
latter with Tsintaosaurus spinorhinus from the Campanian of the Wangshi
Group, Shandong Province, China. This study provided conclusive evidence
of the presence of the Lambeosaurinae in Europe. Tsintaosaurus
spinorhinus and Pararhabdodon isonensis were inferred to form a clade of
basal lambeosaurines characterized by a maxilla with an elevated
articular facet for the jugal (continuous with the ectopterygoid ridge)
and an extremely medially projected symphyseal region of the dentary.
This clade originated in Asia during the middle or late Campanian.
Pararhabdodon isonensis or its ancestors migrated from Asia to the
Iberian island of the European archipelago. Reconstruction of ancestral
areas by Fitch parsimony attributes the European occurrence of P.
isonensis to a single dispersal event from Asia no later than middle to
late Campanian.
